TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is represented before the Court by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The Government are represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON , of ORG , and their Co - agent , PERSON , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE . He entered GPE in DATE , when he was DATE .
DATE , in GPE he married a NORP woman who remained in their country of origin . There , the spouses had a daughter in DATE and a son in DATE .
In DATE , the applicant ’s wife and his CARDINAL children entered GPE under the rules regarding family unification . In DATE the spouses had another daughter .
On DATE the applicant was detained on remand , charged with sexual offences allegedly having been committed throughout DATE against his eldest daughter as from the time when she was DATE .

An indictment of DATE was submitted to ORG ( PERSON ) , before which the applicant , the daughter and CARDINAL witnesses were heard , including a teacher in whom the daughter had confided , and a police officer who worked at the institution where the daughter had been placed . The applicant pleaded not guilty and explained among other things that he had commenced sleeping on a mattress in his daughter ’s bedroom DATE , DATE , usually in connection with him having come home from TIME out . He did not wish to wake up his wife and his youngest daughter , who slept in the spouses’ bedroom . Also , he was suffering from backache , and it did him good to sleep on a flat surface . In response to the fact that a forensic examination of the sheets in his daughter ’s bedroom revealed sperm cells , the applicant explained that he had slept with his wife in the daughter ’s bedroom .
Before the ORG the daughter explained among other things that the applicant had started sleeping with her when she was DATE in connection with her mother having gone to GPE for a funeral .
The applicant ’s wife was called to the witness stand but declined to give testimony against her husband . She was therefore exempted in accordance with ORG ( Retsplejeloven ) .

By judgment of DATE , pursuant to sections CARDINAL ; CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL taken together with subsection CARDINAL ; and CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL taken together with subsection CARDINAL ; section CARDINAL ; and partly section CARDINAL of LAW ( PERSON ) the applicant was convicted of having sexually abused his daughter by resorting to violence and threats during the period from DATE until DATE

The ORG found it established that the sexual abuse involved masturbation , oral sex , and attempts of intercourse , the latter having failed only because the daughter had expressed pain and because it had been physically impossible for the applicant .

The applicant was also convicted pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW for having uttered threats against his daughter ’s life in that , after the sexual abuse had been reported to the police , he sent her a Short Message Service ( SMS ) in which he wrote : “ you are superfluous in GPE , if I see you on the street , I will kill you . This I promise ” . Also , it was found established that he had sent her an SMS in which he threatened to come and “ fuck her ” if she did not call him within TIME .

The applicant was sentenced to DATE imprisonment . Furthermore , pursuant to section CARDINAL ( ii ) and ( vi ) of LAW ( PERSON ) he was expelled from GPE forever . As to the latter the court noted on the one hand that the applicant had entered GPE when he was DATE , that he had lived there for DATE , and that his father and CARDINAL siblings also lived in GPE . On the other hand the court noted the seriousness and the nature of the crime , that the applicant ’s mother and CARDINAL siblings lived in GPE , that the applicant had maintained strong contact with them and that DATE he had spent his vacation in GPE .

On DATE , on appeal , the judgment was upheld by the High Court of Eastern Denmark ( PERSON ) , before which the applicant ’s wife agreed to testify . She confirmed that in DATE she had been in GPE for DATE to participate in a funeral , and stated among other things that she had initiated a divorce from the applicant .
Leave to appeal against the judgment to ORG ( Højesteret ) was refused by the Leave to Appeal Board ( Procesbevillingsnævnet ) on DATE .
By judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG granted the applicant ’s wife a divorce and awarded her custody over the CARDINAL children . The applicant did not request access to any of his children .
On DATE the applicant was released from prison and expelled to GPE .
The applicant ’s father and brother who lived in GPE also returned to GPE , and the applicant ’s family in GPE thus consisted of his parents and CARDINAL siblings .

In DATE the applicant ’s wife went to GPE to obtain a divorce from the applicant also according to NORP law . It appears that the applicant objected thereto and that the proceedings thereon are still pending .
During DATE the applicant ’s CARDINAL youngest children visited him and his family in GPE .
During DATE the applicant ’s son stayed with him in GPE .

Section CARDINAL :
CARDINAL . NORP “ In deciding on expulsion , regard must be had to the question whether expulsion must be assumed to be particularly burdensome , in particular because of :
( i ) the alien ’s ties with the NORP community , including whether the alien came to GPE in his childhood or DATE ;
( ii ) the duration of the alien ’s stay in GPE ;
( iii ) the alien ’s age , health , and other personal circumstances ;
( iv ) the alien ’s ties with persons living in GPE ;
( v ) the consequences of the expulsion for the alien ’s close relatives livening in GPE ;
( vi ) the alien ’s slight or non - existent ties with his country of origin or any other country in which he may be expected to take up residence ;

( vii ) the risk that , in cases other that those mentioned in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) , the alien will be ill - treated in his country of origin or any other country in which he may be expected to take up residence .
CARDINAL . An alien may be expelled pursuant to section CARDINAL ) to ( vi ) unless the circumstances mentioned in subsection CARDINAL above constitute a decisive argument against doing so . ”
